title: Tushar Ramani
author: Tushar Ramani
content: Hello, fellow Bitcoiners,Encouraged by some friends, I’ve been thinking about starting a DCA (Dollar Cost Averaging) strategy into Bitcoin, but I haven’t been able to get started yet. What would be the easiest platform with low fees to use? Automatic purchases aren’t a necessity since I’m fine with buying manually, but having that option would be a bonus.Looking forward to your suggestions!

Looking forward to your suggestions!You were here in this forum for nearly more than 6 years. Now, you suddenly came after 3  years to post shit like this.

comments.author: Oshosondy
comments.body: You can try OKX or MEXC. The last time I withdraw on MEXC was 2 weeks ago and the withdrawal fee was £0.8.Another approach is that you can first withdraw to lightning wallet if the money is significantly low. After like 4 withdraw, you can move the money back to exchange and withdraw it to a noncustodial wallet. If you withdraw to a noncustodial withdraw like every week, be ready to consolidate your inputs when the transaction fee is low.

comments.author: coolcoinz
comments.body: Quote from: xmrhopium on January 22, 2025, 05:30:50 PMQuote from: Tushar Ramani on January 22, 2025, 05:21:35 PMHello, fellow Bitcoiners,Encouraged by some friends, I’ve been thinking about starting a DCA (Dollar Cost Averaging) strategy into Bitcoin, but I haven’t been able to get started yet. Looking forward to your suggestions!You were here in this forum for nearly more than 6 years. Now, you suddenly came after 3  years to post shit like this. Hasn't been able to get started yet. That's his own words. 1 or 6 years? That makes no difference. Nobody counts that. Many people mistake DCA for a method where you send some money to an exchange every week or every month and buy a fraction of bitcoin, but you can always send more money up front and then log in and buy some bitcoin, spending maybe 10% of that money. Whatever platform you choose, going cheap is not a good idea. DCA doesn't mean spending $1 a day on bitcoin. This will never make a difference in your life. On the other hand, if you're planning to buy at least $100 worth of bitcoin every month, you can always save up on fees and withdraw once you get to a larger sum like $500+

comments.author: franky1
comments.body: most people are already hoarding coin from the previous 2023-24 correction bottom opportunity to DCA... whereby they are now preparing to slowdown their DCA now the prices are moving into ATH territory with the ultimate ATH(all time high) approaching in a few monthsthere is still opportunity to put some in for a couple months and see a profit when it hits ATH this year.. but then you will be waiting another 3 years through the correction and the halving in next cycle for that to break even. before seeing profit again if you DCA too high.. so many are just going to DCA a month or so, take a break at ATH and then DCA in the correction when prices come down from the ATH

comments.author: Dr.Bitcoin_Strange
comments.body: @OP, your pattern of DCA will be determined by you, how do I mean? Well, it depends on the availability of funds you want to invest into bitcoin, if you already have a huge sum of money that you want to invest, you can start by investing just a small percent of it every week but if the money is not available, perhaps you are earning salary on monthly basis and you intend to invest just some percent of it into bitcoin, that means you will be investing monthly. So, it depends on what you want and your income flow.
